From the 1950s until the early 1980s, the 'television play' was a popular
television programming genre in the United Kingdom, with a shorter span in the
United States. The genre was often associated with the social realist-influenced
British drama style known as "kitchen sink realism", which depicted the social
issues facing working-class families. [[Armchair Theatre]] (ABC, later Thames,
1956â1974), [[The Wednesday Play]] (BBC, 1964â1970) and [[Play for Today]] (BBC,
1970â1984) received praise from critics for their quality. In the United States,
television plays were seen mainly from 1948 to 1961, the period of live TV
dramas which framed the Golden Age of Television.

The term 'television play' is a partial misnomer. Although the earliest works
were marked by television drama drawing on its theatrical roots, with live
performances telecast from the television studio, a shift towards shooting on
film occurred in the late 1970s, utilising techniques and working methods common
in the cinema, but use of the term has persisted.
